012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;
013
014import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
015import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
016
017/**
018 * Test of a very simple form of conditional execution in the deployment
019 * descriptor using only the {@code <implementor name>} specified for an
020 * {@code <implementor block>}.
021 * <p>
022 * When a deployment descriptor is executed, the config setting
023 * {@code pljava.implementors} determines which {@code <implementor block>}s
024 * will be executed (in addition to all of the plain {@code <SQL statement>}s
025 * that are not tagged with an implementor name). The default setting of
026 * {@code pljava.implementors} is simply {@code postgresql}.
027 * <p>
028 * In this example, an {@code SQLAction} (with the default implementor name
029 * {@code PostgreSQL} so it should always execute) tests some condition and,
030 * based on the result, adds {@code LifeIsGood} to the list of recognized
031 * implementor names.
032 * <p>
033 * Later {@code SQLAction}s with that implementor name should also be executed,
034 * while those with a different, unrecognized implementor should not.
035 * <p>
036 * That is what happens at <em>deployment</em> (or undeployment) time, when the
037 * jar has been loaded into the target database and the deployment descriptor is
038 * being processed.
039 * <p>
040 * The {@code provides} attributes matter at
041 * <em>compile</em> time: they are hints to the DDR generator so it will be sure
042 * to write the {@code SQLAction} that tests the condition ahead of whatever
043 * depends on the condition having been tested. The example illustrates that
044 * {@code implementor} is treated also as an implicit {@code requires}.
045 * <p>
046 * Note: while ISO SQL/JRT specifies that an {@code <implementor name>} is an
047 * SQL identifier, which would match case-insensitively unless quoted, PL/Java
048 * treats {@code provides} elements as arbitrary strings that can only be
049 * matched with identical spelling and case. Therefore, the matching of the
050 * implicit {@code requires} of an {@code <implementor name>} and the explicit
051 * {@code provides} on an {@code SQLAction} depends on the {@code implementor}
052 * and {@code provides} values being supplied with identical spelling and case,
053 * <p>
054 * The dependency created when matching {@code implementor} to {@code provides}
055 * differs in three ways from an explicit dependency between {@code requires}
056 * and {@code provides}:
057 * <ul>
058 * <li>It is weak: if there is nothing declared that {@code provides} it,
059 * that's not an error; affected {@code <implementor block>}s will just be
060 * placed as late in the generated DDR as other dependencies allow, in case
061 * something in the preceding actions will be setting those implementor names.
062 * <li>It does not have its sense reversed when generating
063 * the {@code REMOVE} actions of the deployment descriptor. Ordinary
064 * requirements do, so the dependent objects get dropped before the things they
065 * depend on.
066 * But the code for setting a conditional implementor name has to be placed
067 * ahead of the uses of the name, whether deploying or undeploying.
068 * <li>An {@code SQLAction} setting an implementor name does not need to have
069 * any {@code remove=} actions. If it does not (the usual case), its
070 * {@code install=} actions will be used in both sections of the deployment
071 * descriptor.
072 * </ul>
073 * <p>
074 * This example adds {@code LifeIsGood} ahead of the prior content of
075 * {@code pljava.implementors}. Simply replacing the value would stop the
076 * default implementor PostgreSQL being recognized, probably not what's wanted.
077 * The final {@code true} argument to {@code set_config} makes the setting
078 * local, so it is reverted when the transaction completes.
079 * <p>
080 * In addition to the goodness-of-life examples, this file also generates
081 * one or more statements setting PostgreSQL-version-based implementor names
082 * that are relied on by various other examples in this directory.
083 */
084@SQLAction(provides={"LifeIsGood","LifeIsNotGood"}, install=
085    "SELECT CASE 42 WHEN 42 THEN " +
086    " set_config('pljava.implementors', 'LifeIsGood,' || " +
087    "  current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
088    "ELSE " +
089    " set_config('pljava.implementors', 'LifeIsNotGood,' || " +
090    "  current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
091    "END"
092)
093
094@SQLAction(implementor="LifeIsGood", install=
095    "SELECT javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'ConditionalDDR looking good!')"
096)
097
098@SQLAction(implementor="LifeIsNotGood", install=
099    "SELECT javatest.logmessage('WARNING', " +
100    " 'ConditionalDDR: This should not be executed')"
101)
102
103@SQLAction(provides="postgresql_ge_100000", install=
104    "SELECT CASE WHEN" +
105    " 100000 <= CAST(current_setting('server_version_num') AS integer)" +
106    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_ge_100000,' || " +
107    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
108    "END"
109)
110public class ConditionalDDR
111{
112    private ConditionalDDR() { } // do not instantiate
113
114    /**
115     * Tests class names in the supplied order, returning false as soon as any
116     * cannot be found by the class loader(s) available to the examples jar, or
117     * true if all can be found.
118     */
119    @Function(variadic = true, provides = "presentOnClassPath")
120    public static boolean presentOnClassPath(String[] className)
121    {
122        try
123        {
124            ClassLoader myLoader = ConditionalDDR.class.getClassLoader();
125            for ( String cn : className )
126                Class.forName(cn, false, myLoader);
127            return true;
128        }
129        catch ( ClassNotFoundException e )
130        {
131            return false;
132        }
133    }
134}
